column4: zykotick9 the system wide path originates in /etc/environment
so if I add a directory to the $PATH defined in /etc/environment, it will be present in every shell no matter what?
yes. but you will need to at least logout and back in first, if not reboot

I have a question for you: I've added /foo to the path defined in /etc/environment, and now if I type which bar then /foo/bar is returned.  However, sudo which bar returns nothing -- typing sudo foo says "sudo: foo: command not found"

I have a question for you: I have a program bar in directory /foo.  I've added /foo to the path defined in /etc/environment and rebooted, and now which bar returns /foo/bar but sudo which bar returns nothing.  Moreover, bar works but sudo bar results in: "sudo: bar: command not found" -- do you have any idea what's wrong?
check out the manpage for sudo. from memory sudo, by default, clears the path. there are options to change that behaviour
once again from memory, the best way to fix this would be to also add /foo to the path sudo uses. this should be configurable in /etc/sudoers I think
I am baffled: sudo echo $PATH shows /foo is in $PATH, but sudo foo fails with "sudo: foo: command not found".  I'll check out the sudoers file
look at variable secure_path in man sudoers
I notice that in sudoers, there's the line "Defaults    env_reset"
there is no secure_path in /etc/sudoers for me
no, leave that one alone. by default secure_path is set to </usr/local/sbin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/sbin:/usr/bin:/sbin:/bin:/usr/X11R6/bin so just add you /foo
that info is from "man sudoers" there are a lot of settings that have defaults and will not be in the sudoers file.

OK, so if env_reset is set and I also specify secure_path to be /foo + the default, the environment will be reset (as it is currently) but the PATH will be forcefully set to what I've specified, right?
yes that is correct. don't forget to use sudoedit to edit the sudoers file, it saves you from disaster!
righto, i'll give it a try. thanks
I think that sudoedit still defaults to useing vi as an editor, you may want to either read up on using vi, or check the manpage for sudoedit to find out how to use a different editor with it
